docs.title: Tax Return Guide (2025)
docs.text: A plain-English guide to filing taxes, saving money legally, and understanding the US tax system.

docs.title: What This Book Is
docs.text:
Most tax guides are either too vague to be useful or written for accountants. This book is different.

In plain English — with real dollar amounts, real examples, and zero jargon — you will learn how to:

  • File your own taxes without paying someone hundreds of dollars
  • Legally reduce what you owe using strategies most people miss
  • Understand every form the IRS sends you
  • Handle side hustle and self-employment income without getting blindsided in April
  • Plan year-round so tax season is never a surprise again

Whether you are filing for the first time, dealing with 1099 income, or trying to stop leaving money on the table — this guide is for you.

docs.title: The 12 Chapters
docs.text: # Chapter What You Will Learn 1 Understanding Your Tax Situation Filing status, income types, what the IRS actually taxes 2 Filing Your Return Step by Step How to file, free options, standard vs itemized deductions 3 Legal Tax Reduction Strategies Credits, deductions, and retirement contributions that cut your bill 4 Side Hustle & Self-Employment Taxes SE tax, quarterly payments, business deductions 5 Year-Round Tax Planning W-4 adjustments, tax-loss harvesting, staying ahead 6 Tax Forms Deep Dive Every box on your W-2, 1099, and 1040 explained 7 Investments & Capital Gains Taxes Short vs long-term rates, dividends, crypto 8 Real Estate & Rental Property Taxes Depreciation, deductions, selling your home 9 Advanced Strategies & Loopholes Backdoor Roth, Augusta Rule, Solo 401(k), and more 10 State Taxes Overview How state taxes work, no-income-tax states, multi-state filing 11 IRS Audits & How to Avoid Them Red flags, audit triggers, what to do if selected 12 Free Filing Resources & Tools IRS Free File, VITA, Direct File, and the best free tools

docs.title: How to Use This Book
docs.text:
• Complete beginner? Start with Chapter 1.
  • Need to file right now? Jump to Chapter 2.
  • Have a side hustle? Start with Chapter 4.
  • Want to pay less in taxes? Start with Chapter 3, then go to Chapter 9.

This book uses 2025 tax law

All brackets, limits, and rules reflect the 2025 tax year (filed in early 2026). Rules change annually — always verify current limits at IRS.gov.

docs.title: Course Title
docs.text: Tax Return Guide: A Plain-English Guide to Filing, Saving, and Winning at Taxes (2025)

docs.title: Course Overview
docs.text:
This is a 12-chapter intelligent textbook for the general public covering the complete US federal and state tax system. Unlike most tax resources that are either too vague or written for professionals, this guide uses plain English, real dollar amounts, and practical examples to walk any adult through filing their own taxes, legally minimizing what they owe, and building smart tax habits year-round.

The book covers W-2 employees, 1099 contractors, side hustlers, investors, rental property owners, and anyone who wants to stop overpaying or underpaying the IRS.

docs.title: Writing Tone and Style
docs.text:
• Voice: A knowledgeable friend who is a CPA — someone who gives you straight answers, not hedged non-answers driven by liability
  • Language: Plain English, no jargon without explanation
  • Numbers: Real dollar amounts in every example, not vague percentages
  • Action-oriented: Each chapter ends with a "What To Do Right Now" section
  • Non-judgmental: Whether you owe money or are getting a refund, no shame — just actionable steps

docs.title: Target Audience
docs.text:
• Primary: General public adults filing US taxes
  • Includes: First-time filers, W-2 employees, 1099 contractors, side hustlers, gig workers, investors, landlords, and anyone who wants to pay less in taxes legally
  • Age range: 18 and older
  • Educational level: Adult continuing education / general public
  • Prior knowledge required: Basic arithmetic and reading comprehension — no tax or financial background needed

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Basic arithmetic (addition, subtraction, percentages)
  • Ability to read a form or document
  • No prior tax, finance, or accounting knowledge required

docs.title: The 12 Chapters
docs.text:
1. Understanding Your Tax Situation — Filing status, income types, taxable vs non-taxable income, how the IRS views your financial life
  2. Filing Your Return Step by Step — Standard vs itemized deductions, tax credits, how to actually file, free filing options
  3. Legal Tax Reduction Strategies — Retirement contributions, HSA, education credits, charitable giving, and other legal ways to reduce your tax bill
  4. Side Hustle & Self-Employment Taxes — SE tax calculation, quarterly estimated payments, deductible business expenses, Schedule C
  5. Year-Round Tax Planning — W-4 withholding optimization, tax-loss harvesting, Roth conversions, staying ahead of April
  6. Tax Forms Deep Dive — Every box on the W-2, 1099-NEC, 1099-INT, 1099-DIV, and 1040 explained in plain English
  7. Investments & Capital Gains Taxes — Short-term vs long-term capital gains rates, dividend taxation, cryptocurrency, wash sale rule
  8. Real Estate & Rental Property Taxes — Depreciation, rental income and expense deductions, selling your primary residence (\(250k/\)500k exclusion)
  9. Advanced Strategies & Loopholes — Backdoor Roth IRA, Augusta Rule, Solo 401(k), Dependent Care FSA, health insurance deduction for self-employed, energy credits
  10. State Taxes Overview — How state income taxes work, the 9 no-income-tax states, multi-state filing, state-specific deductions
  11. IRS Audits & How to Avoid Them — Common audit triggers, what the IRS looks for, how to respond if selected, record-keeping best practices
  12. Free Filing Resources & Tools — IRS Free File, VITA program, IRS Direct File, best free tax software, and when to hire a professional

docs.title: Learning Objectives by Bloom's Taxonomy
docs.text: After this course, students will be able to demonstrate competencies at each of the following levels:

docs.title: Remember
docs.text:
• Recall the 2025 federal tax brackets and standard deduction amounts
  • Name the most common tax forms (W-2, 1099, 1040, Schedule C)
  • Identify the four filing statuses and their eligibility requirements
  • Recall IRS record retention rules (3-year, 6-year, and 7-year requirements)
  • Recognize the difference between a W-2 (employee) and a 1099 (contractor) form
  • List categories of income that are NOT taxable (gifts, inheritances, certain employer benefits)

docs.title: Understand
docs.text:
• Explain the difference between a tax deduction and a tax credit
  • Describe how marginal tax brackets work (and bust the "higher bracket" myth)
  • Explain what self-employment tax is and who pays it
  • Explain the difference between a tax refund and actually reducing your tax liability
  • Describe the consequences of filing late or missing a payment deadline
  • Explain what adjusted gross income (AGI) is and why it determines eligibility for many deductions and credits

docs.title: Apply
docs.text:
• Calculate your taxable income after standard deduction
  • Determine whether to take the standard deduction or itemize
  • Complete a Schedule C for basic self-employment income
  • Calculate quarterly estimated tax payments

docs.title: Analyze
docs.text:
• Compare the after-tax cost of traditional vs Roth retirement contributions
  • Analyze whether a side hustle business deduction is legitimate vs a personal expense
  • Compare tax-advantaged account options (HSA, FSA, IRA, 401k) based on income and tax situation
  • Distinguish between legitimate business deductions and personal expenses that do not qualify
  • Break down the components of a total tax bill (federal income tax vs self-employment tax vs FICA)

docs.title: Evaluate
docs.text:
• Assess which legal tax reduction strategies apply to your specific situation
  • Judge when to file yourself vs hire a tax professional
  • Evaluate the audit risk of specific deductions before claiming them
  • Evaluate whether an advanced strategy (Augusta Rule, Backdoor Roth, Solo 401k) applies to your financial situation
  • Assess the true cost of underpaying estimated taxes vs overpaying and receiving a large refund

docs.title: Create
docs.text:
• Build a personalized year-round tax calendar with key deadlines and action items
  • Design a record-keeping system for business and investment expenses
  • Create a tax projection to estimate your refund or balance due before April
  • Capstone: Produce a complete personal tax blueprint — a mock completed 1040, annotated W-2 and 1099 forms, a quarterly estimated tax payment schedule, and a 12-month business deduction tracking log

docs.title: Topics Not Covered
docs.text:
• Advanced corporate tax law (C-corps, S-corps)
  • International tax (FBAR, FATCA, foreign income exclusion)
  • Estate and gift tax (beyond basic overview)
  • Tax court procedures and legal disputes
  • Specific professional advice — this book is educational, not a substitute for a CPA

docs.title: Course Duration
docs.text: Pace Schedule Duration Intensive 1 chapter/day 2 weeks Regular 2 chapters/week 6 weeks Relaxed 1 chapter/week 3 months

docs.title: Expected Outcomes
docs.text:
After completing this guide, you will be able to:

  • File your own federal and state tax return using free tools
  • Calculate how much you owe or your expected refund before filing
  • Identify at least 3 legal deductions or credits you were not previously claiming
  • Set up a quarterly estimated tax system if you have self-employment income
  • Understand every line item on your W-2 and 1099 forms
  • Know exactly which records to keep and for how long
  • Have a year-round tax plan so April is never a surprise

docs.title: 1. Target Audience (−1 pt)
docs.text: The audience is well-described but does not use a formal education-level classification. The skill framework expects a category such as "adult continuing education" or "general public / all levels." This is cosmetic but useful for learning graph calibration.

docs.title: 2. Learning Outcomes Header (−1 pt)
docs.text: The Bloom's Taxonomy section is titled "Learning Objectives by Bloom's Taxonomy" but is missing the standard lead-in statement: "After this course, students will be able to…" This phrase helps the learning graph generator anchor all concepts to learner outcomes.

docs.title: 3. Remember Level (−2 pts)
docs.text:
Only 3 outcomes present. Missing outcomes that would unlock additional concept nodes:

  • Recall IRS record retention requirements (3 years, 6 years, 7 years rules)
  • Recognize the difference between a W-2 and a 1099
  • List the types of income that are NOT taxable (gifts, inheritances, some benefits)

docs.title: 4. Understand Level (−2 pts)
docs.text:
Only 3 outcomes. Missing outcomes:

  • Explain the difference between a tax refund and actually owing less tax
  • Describe what happens when you file late or miss a payment
  • Explain what adjusted gross income (AGI) is and why it matters

docs.title: 5. Analyze Level (−2 pts)
docs.text:
One outcome uses the verb "Evaluate" (a higher Bloom's level) instead of an Analyze-level verb. This creates a taxonomy overlap. Also needs 4+ outcomes:

  • Needs fix: "Evaluate which tax-advantaged accounts best match your situation" → reword to "Compare tax-advantaged account options based on income and tax situation"
  • Missing: "Distinguish between legitimate business deductions and personal expenses"
  • Missing: "Break down the components of a tax bill (income tax vs SE tax vs FICA)"

docs.title: 6. Evaluate Level (−1 pt)
docs.text:
Strong but could add:

  • "Evaluate whether a given advanced tax strategy (Augusta Rule, backdoor Roth) applies to your financial situation"

docs.title: 7. Create Level (−2 pts)
docs.text:
3 outcomes are present but no capstone project is described. Suggested capstone:

  • Missing: "Produce a complete personal tax blueprint: a mock completed 1040, annotated W-2/1099, a quarterly estimated tax schedule, and a business deduction log"

docs.title: Priority 1 — Add capstone to Create level
docs.text:
A capstone project description significantly improves learning graph richness. Suggested addition:

Create a complete personal tax blueprint: a mock completed 1040, an annotated W-2/1099 pair, a quarterly estimated tax schedule, and a business deduction log for one year of side hustle income.

docs.title: Priority 2 — Fix the Analyze/Evaluate taxonomy slip
docs.text: Move "Evaluate which tax-advantaged accounts best match your situation" from Analyze to Evaluate, and replace it with a true analysis outcome using verbs like: distinguish, differentiate, compare, break down, categorize, examine.

docs.title: Priority 3 — Add 2 more outcomes to Remember and Understand
docs.text: These unlock more foundational concept nodes in the learning graph. Use verbs: recall, recognize, list, name, define (Remember) and explain, describe, summarize, classify (Understand).

docs.title: Priority 4 — Add formal audience level classification
docs.text: Add one line: **Educational level:** Adult continuing education / general public
